channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Amid Grim Economic Forecasts, Cubans Fear a Return to Darker Times
item.media:description: Baracoa, Cuba, in January. Addressing members of Parliament last week, Cuba’s economy minister, Marino Murillo, said the country would have to cut fuel consumption by nearly a third during the second half of the year.
item.description: Recent calls to cut energy usage, along with the faltering economy in Venezuela, which provides much of Cuba’s oil, have left Cubans worried about fuel shortages and blackouts.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Tribunal Rejects Beijing’s Claims in South China Sea
item.description: An international panel in The Hague delivered a sweeping rebuke of China’s behavior, deciding that its expansive claim to sovereignty over the waters had no legal basis.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: David Cameron Gets Hustled Out of Downing Street, but the Cat Stays
item.media:description: Theresa May, Britain’s incoming prime minister, walked past Larry the Cat on her way to attend a cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street in London on Tuesday.
item.description: The only resident of 10 Downing Street to be spared the indignity of one of Britain’s fastest political transitions in recent memory will be Larry the Cat.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: News Analysis: Theresa May, Untested and Ascending to Manage ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Theresa May leaving 10 Downing Street after attending a cabinet meeting there on Tuesday.
item.description: No one is quite sure if Ms. May, the next British prime minister, can successfully balance the nation’s economic and political needs with the exit from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Thousands Protest Sex Assaults at Bull Run in Pamplona, Spain
item.media:description: Protesting sexual violence against women during the San Fermín festival in Pamplona, Spain.
item.description: Fifteen people have been arrested in separate cases of sexual assault at the annual San Fermín festival, amid heightened awareness of such attacks in Europe.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Cease-Fire Appears to Hold in South Sudan’s Capital, Juba
item.description: Hours after a truce was reached to end fighting between rival groups of soldiers, thousands of civilians remained in churches and schools out of fear and uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Pastor in Zimbabwe Is Arrested as Anger Toward Robert Mugabe Builds
item.media:description: The Rev. Evan Mawarire, second from right, who organized an antigovernment protest last week, arriving on Tuesday at a police station in Harare, Zimbabwe.
item.description: The activism of the Rev. Evan Mawarire, who organized the country’s largest protests in a decade, has galvanized public outrage over the president’s rule.
item.dc:creator: HOPEWELL CHIN’ONO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: A Saudi Morals Enforcer Called for a More Liberal Islam. Then the Death Threats Began.
item.media:description: Saudi women standing on the opposite side of the hall from the men at the Amex Luxury Expo in Riyadh in March.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: A longtime morals enforcer began to question the rules. He told his story to a Times correspondent who spent weeks in Saudi Arabia trying to understand its hyper-conservative strain of Islam, which is often blamed for terrorism.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Malcolm Turnbull Claims Victory in Australia Election After Rival Concedes
item.description: The electoral commission has forecast that Mr. Turnbull’s Liberal Party-led coalition could win a combined 76 seats, which would give it an absolute majority.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Two Hostages From Bangladesh Standoff Are Still Missing
item.media:description: Tahmid Hasib Khan, in a photo provided by his family, remains missing after being detained by Dhaka police following an attack on a restaurant in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
item.description: Amnesty International urged the government to clarify the whereabouts of one of the men, who were questioned after surviving a terrorist attack on a Dhaka restaurant.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and GEETA ANAND
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn Will Be on Ballot as Labour Party Schedules Election in Britain
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of the opposition Labour Party, in London on Tuesday. He had campaigned for Britain to remain in the European Union.
item.description: Mr. Corbyn faced a revolt by fellow Labour lawmakers after Britain’s June 23 referendum to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Memo From Paris: ‘That Ignoramus’: 2 French Scholars of Radical Islam Turn Bitter Rivals
item.media:description: Muslims gathered last month in Mantes-La-Jolie, France, a Paris suburb, for a walk in tribute to two victims of a stabbing attack by an assailant claiming to act in the name of the Islamic State.
item.description: A falling-out between the academics, Olivier Roy and Gilles Kepel, presents an important question: Which man holds the key to understanding the phenomenon?
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: 5 Things to Know About Theresa May, Britain’s Next Prime Minister
item.media:description: Theresa May, the British home secretary, is poised to become the country’s next prime minister.
item.description: Ms. May is set to become the country’s leader on Wednesday. She’s been a long-serving cabinet minister and has promised to guide Britain out of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Letter From Europe: Turkey Makes Overtures to Minorities, but Old Enmities Linger
item.media:description: The unfinished Statue of Humanity, a monument to Armenian-Turkish reconciliation, in Kars, Turkey, in 2009. It was demolished in 2011.
item.description: The government denies the Armenian genocide and threatens to punish countries that recognize it, but there are signs that history may be getting its due.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Sinosphere: Beetle Is Named in Honor of Xi Jinping, but China Aims to Squash the News
item.media:description: The Rhyzodiastes (Temoana) xii, discovered last year on Hainan Island, was named for President Xi Jinping of China.
item.description: The taxonomic gesture appeared to irritate propaganda bosses, who moved fast to block references to the “Xi beetle” from the nation’s heavily censored internet
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Train Crash in Italy Leaves at Least 25 Dead and Dozens Injured
item.description: The crash occurred around 11:30 a.m. in an olive grove between Andria and Ruvo di Puglia, in the southern region of Puglia.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Korean Official, Calling for Class System, Hears Woofs, Oinks and Outrage
item.media:description: Prime Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn of South Korea
item.description: Comments online expressed anger at an education official who said the country should put in place a structure in which 99 percent of South Koreans should be treated “like dogs and pigs.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Europe Approves New Trans-Atlantic Data Transfer Deal
item.media:description: Penny Pritzker, left, the American secretary of commerce; and Vera Jourova, the European Union’s commissioner in charge of justice, consumers and gender equality, at a news briefing in Brussels on Tuesday after the approval of the new data pact.
item.description: After years of negotiations, Europe agreed to allow thousands of companies to move digital data to the United States, though challenges still lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Sinosphere: Tiananmen Protest Museum in Hong Kong Shuts Its Doors, for Now
item.media:description: A replica of the Goddess of Democracy statue at the June 4th Museum in Hong Kong, along with documents from the 1989 protests.
item.description: The museum, arguing that it had been forced out, said it was searching for a new site but had not found one in time to prevent a temporary closing.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: What in the World: At Mexico’s Top Restaurants, Service Too Good to Be Good
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photos by LuckyImages, sisqopote/shutterstock
item.description: At many of the country’s higher-end establishments, waiters are arguably so attentive it borders on annoying.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: What in the World: Kenya Mocks Its Woes in Wry Verbal Shorthand
item.description: The country’s understated humor comes through in popular Swahili and English euphemisms for life’s annoyances and sins.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: What in the World: A Fire Monkey Can Usher In Chaos. So Can 600 or So Macaques.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photo by Ben Sklar for The New York Times, Eric Thayer/Reuters
item.description: This is a rare Year of the Fire Monkey, an occasion often associated with chaos. Just ask a village in China that’s been overrun by little, loud primates.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: OP-Ed Contributor: England’s Last Gasp of Empire
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II attended a service of the Order of the British Empire in St. Paul’s Cathedral, London, in 2012.
item.media:credit: Geoff Pugh/Daily Telegraph, via Associated Press
item.description: The Brexit vote expressed white Britain’s nostalgia for a lost sense of greatness.
item.dc:creator: BEN JUDAH
item.category: Elizabeth I, Queen of Great Britain
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Theresa May and the Cutthroat Conservatives
item.media:description: Theresa May spoke outside the Houses of Parliament on Monday.
item.media:credit: Dominic Lipinski/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister inherits a raft of challenges, both for the country and within her party.
item.dc:creator: HELEN LEWIS

item.title: Editorial: Testing the Rule of Law in the South China Sea
item.description: China’s reaction to a tribunal’s decision will say much about its approach to international law.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
